section-block.rac_essential-question: What vehicles do we know about? How do they help us?

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written and illustrated by Liesbet Slegers
section-block.rac_book_summary: Vehicles come in so many different shapes and sizes—from cars to ice cream trucks to bulldozers. In this book, you will learn about vehicles you can ride, vehicles that help, and vehicles that do work. Let’s learn what all these different vehicles do!

section-block.rac_body-text: Use two different objects to demonstrate location terms, such as next to, over, and near, to model the use of these words in context.
Play the game Simon Says, using location terms in Simon’s instructions. For example, say: stand near a friend, put a hand under your chin, and so on.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Me and My Cars by Liesbet Slegers.
You know Lala loves all sorts of books. She will love reading about vehicles in this book!
There is a question that I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read.
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What do we use vehicles for?

section.rac_body-text: Focus on Spatial Sense: Ask children to describe where vehicles and people are in relation to each other in the pictures.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What do you think this book is about? What do you like to ride?
The camper is a kind of van that you can sleep in! What do you think might be inside?
The woman is standing behind the delivery van. What is she doing?
What kind of vehicles help people? (MB)
The sick person is inside the ambulance. How does the ambulance help people?
How does a fire engine help people? Look—one fire fighter is above another fire fighter!
How can vehicles help people do work? What kind of vehicles do work? (MB)
What does the garbage truck do? What happens to the garbage once it goes in the back of the truck?
How does a crane truck do work?
Let’s talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What do we use vehicles for?
section.rac_body-text: Have children Turn and Talk. Then use Equity Sticks to pick a few children to share.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: We use vehicles to drive places.
We use vehicles to help people.
We use vehicles to do work.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences about vehicles children recognize from their daily lives.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What do we use garbage trucks for?
How do we use vehicles to help people?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children develop a sense of spatial relationships early on and they use perceptual information to guide their own motions and interactions. Encourage children to describe the position of classmates or items using location words and phrases so that they can start to describe how they interact with their environment.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: OUR COMMUNITY | WEEK 4: Vehicles at Work

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Classify and Organize
section-block.rac_body-text: Point out to children that items like vehicles can be sorted by things about them that you can see, like color or size, and also by things they do, like move things or help people. Practice sorting by having children sort themselves according to something you can see, like shirt color. Provide support as needed. Re-sort by a different attribute, such as wearing short/long sleeves.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we will revisit some pages of Me and My Cars by Liesbet Slegers to look more closely at parts of the book.
Clifford loves to sort things that he reads about. It helps him understand and remember what he’s reading.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread part of the story and use our classify and organize Mind Builder to learn more about vehicles.
section.rac_body-text: Focus on Classification: As you read, point out similarities and differences between the vehicles in each category.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This section is about vehicles we ride in. These are the cars and trucks we take to get places, and that bring goods to us.
We can sort vehicles by size, or how big they are. Is a bus bigger or smaller than a car? We can also sort them by what they do. How are a car and a bus like each other? How are they different? (MB)
We can also sort vehicles by the sounds they make. Which vehicles have sirens? (MB)
What do tractors do? How is it different from a car?
What does the garbage truck do? Is it like what a tractor does? Would you sort them into the same group as cars and buses? Why or why not? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Ask children to think of a vehicle from the book that they want to pretend to be. Have each child share which vehicle they want to pretend to be, and turn to that page in the book for them to review.

Once children have chosen their vehicles, have them pretend to be those vehicles by sounding like them or doing the work that the vehicle does. As a class, sort the vehicles represented by each child into different categories. You can sort by colors, sizes, sounds, or other attributes that children think of.
Transcribe children’s speech as they describe different types of vehicles and the categories they belong in.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: When classifying, children may instinctively recognize the similarities or differences between items without being able to verbalize them. Help children understand the idea of sorting by attribute, or category, by sorting and re-sorting a small set of items. First sort by one attribute, like color, size, or shape, and then re-sort the same set by a different attribute.

section-block.rac_body-text: Explain to children that when you count, each number represents a quantity one larger. Demonstrate by adding Connecting Cubes one at a time and checking the total.
Review the numbers one to ten with children. Practice counting out loud from one to ten while doing an action like standing on one foot. Encourage children to count along.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread Me and My Cars by Liesbet Slegers.
Lala loves reading books with things she can count!
Different vehicles are used for different reasons. As we read today, I want you to think about this question: How do the vehicles in the book help us?
How many wheels do you see on each side of the car? Let’s count and notice the numbers as we count.
How many wheels do you see on the ice cream truck? How does the ice cream truck help us?
How many wheels do you see on each side of the semi-truck? Let’s count! Is it the same as a car?
Why do you think a semi-truck has more wheels than a car? How is a semi-truck helpful?
How many cars does this car transporter carry? Let’s pretend to put one more on it. How many are there now? The next number counted means one more.
How does the car transporter help people?
Why are the police officers putting cones on the road? How many cones are inside the van? How many cones are on the road?
How can police officers be helpful?
Where do you usually find tractors? How does a tractor help?
What do bulldozers do? How might bulldozers help us?
The book says that a dump truck can carry dirt. What else could a dump truck carry?
Did you listen and remember as we read the story today? How do the vehicles in the book help us?
section.rac_body-text: Give children time to Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to ask children to share their responses.
Share a pen with children as you work together to write about the kinds of vehicles they saw this morning. Count the vehicle types together when you’re done.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How does a car transporter help us?
Car transporters help us m____ (move) cars.
Car transporters help us move cars.
What is another type of vehicle that helps us?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children might want to use words that they find difficult to pronounce. Ambulance, bulldozer, delivery van, and excavator are multi-syllabic words that may take practice to say completely and correctly. Schedule a few minutes to help these children practice correct pronunciation.

section-block.rac_body-text: Review the names of two-dimensional shapes with children. Use Pattern Blocks to show how basic shapes can combine to make images.
Play a game like charades where the whole group acts out different vehicles. Children’s acting out should include motions and sounds, but no real words.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: We are going to read The Wheels on the Bus. It is a poster and song about different vehicles.
Me and My Cars and The Wheels on the Bus each focus on vehicles. Let’s look for other connections between the two!
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show Me and My Cars book cover.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What vehicles do we know about? How do they help us?

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to Vehicles at Work
section.rac_body-text: Focus on Shapes: As you read, review the different images on the chart and point out shapes. Discuss building vehicles out of different shapes.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What shape are the wheels? How do the wheels move? What shapes could we use to make a bus?
What is different about a plane and the other vehicles we read about? How do the wings go swoosh?
Does a car make any sounds other than the horn? What does a car sound like? What shapes would you use to make a car?
What is different about a boat and other vehicles we read about? How do you move the oar to row a boat?
The engine chugs as the train moves. What other noises do trains make? What shapes can you find on the train?
What shapes could you use to build diggers? How do they move?

section.rac_body-text: Provide found objects (buttons, paper plates, paper towel tubes, etc) and various-sized cut out shapes, along with coloring materials. Ask children to make a vehicle using these materials and at least two different shapes.
Provide a writing prompt about how vehicles do work and give feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: One way children classify objects at an early age is by identifying shapes. At first, they simply recognize the shape. As their understanding of geometry develops, they learn to recognize shapes regardless of position or size. Children also develop the language skills to identify the characteristics of each shape.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: OUR COMMUNITY | WEEK 4: Vehicles at Work

section-block.rac_body-text: Discuss how different vehicles move. Remind children to use location words when they describe vehicles’ positions.
Adapt “Old McDonald Had a Farm” to “Old McDonald in a City,” by making the noises of helicopters, trains, and other vehicles. Model gestures to go with each vehicle in the song.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s read Me and My Cars one last time this week.
Lala loves making sounds and motions like vehicles while reading.
We have learned about different vehicles. When we read today, I want you to think about this question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What kind of work do vehicles do?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread the book one more time together, this time with volunteers acting out the how the vehicles move.
What shape are the car’s wheels? Do wheels ever have a different shape? Why not? Let’s all move our arms like car wheels.
What shapes do you see in a semi-truck? Let’s all beep two times like a semi-truck!
Let’s all make noises like an ambulance, and move our arms like ambulance wheels!
Sometimes a fire engine makes loud noises. A fire engine makes different noises than an ambulance. Let’s all make fire engine noises!
Why do you think fire engines and ambulances make loud noises?
How many wheels does the tow truck have on each side?
How does a street sweeper sweep the streets? Can you use location words to say where the brushes are on the sweeper? Let’s all show how it works with our hands!
How does an excavator move? How does it work?
How do you get the dirt or other stuff out of the dump truck? Let’s all move like a dump truck!
What kind of work do vehicles do?
section.rac_body-text: Guide children to Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to ask children to share their responses.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: They help get people to the hospital.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write a story about a type of vehicle and include its special features.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What work does a fire engine do?
A fire engine helps put out f____ (fires).
A fire engine helps put out fires.
What are some ways we could sort vehicles into groups?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children from different cultures and with different home languages may have different ways to make the sounds for each vehicle. Encourage children to share and compare the vehicle sounds. Comparing these sounds provides an opportunity for children to share an aspect of their home languages with the class.
